sense.name: moment of beginning
sense.commentary: START[+event] The most common sense. The event of starting, in a fairly general way, either with or without an causal agent. Think of this as the moment at which something begins.
sense.examples: I knew from the start that we were a perfect couple. I got my start in Hollywood because my uncle was a director. The pitcher had over a hundred starts in his career. The exact start of the war was hard to pinpoint. We got a late start on the day. The play always has a ten o'clock start. He was responsible for the start of negotiations.

sense.name: first part
sense.examples: The start of the race was full of hills. I thought the start of the movie was a little boring.

sense.name: starting place
sense.commentary: Refers to a location, not a moment in time. The place at which something begins.
sense.examples: We're only about a mile from the start. The start of the race was located in a cornfield. The start line had been painted on the ground.

sense.name: involuntary motion
sense.commentary: START[+event] A term that describes a bodily motion, usually indicating surprise or some strong emotion. A little jump.
sense.examples: John awoke from his nightmare with a start. She gave a start when I touched her on the shoulder.

sense.name: amount of head start
sense.commentary: START[+event] The advantage that is gained by starting before others do. A kind of possession that a person can have; it can have a definite size.
sense.examples: John only won because he got a head start. With an hour's start on us, they'll be hard to catch.

sense.name: starting signal
sense.commentary: START[+event] The thing that is used to begin an event, usually a race.
sense.examples: The start for the race was a loud electronic beep.
